Kural_Info.Tamil_Text: நகையுள்ளும் இன்னா திகழ்ச்சி பகையுள்ளும்பண்புள பாடறிவார் மாட்டு.
Kural_Info.English_Meaning: Contempt is evil though in sport. They who man's nature know, E'en in their wrath, a courteous mind will show.

Layered_Composition.Foreground: A dramatic scene of conflict between two ancient Tamil figures. One figure ('Paadari vaar') who possesses deep character ('Panbu') is visibly angry or opposed to the other.
Layered_Composition.Midground: Despite their legitimate anger ('Pagai'), the virtuous person refrains from scorn ('Igazhchi'). Their restraint is visualized as a shield of light that stops their own harsh words from forming.
Layered_Composition.Background: In a separate, smaller vignette, two people are shown joking ('Nagai'), but one's joke turns into a painful insult, causing visible hurt, illustrating the Kural's first point.

Art_Direction.Subject_and_Action: Illustrating the profound character of someone who maintains courtesy and avoids contempt even in the face of enmity, and contrasting it with the harm of scorn even in jest.
Art_Direction.Symbolic_Motifs: The shield of light represents the conscious restraint and good character of the virtuous person. The pained expression in the background vignette highlights the harm of 'igazhchi'.
Art_Direction.Mood_and_Emotion: Dignified restraint, controlled anger, contrasting with casual cruelty.
Art_Direction.Lighting_and_Color: The main scene has dramatic, high-contrast lighting, highlighting the tension. The virtuous person has a calm, golden aura of control, while the background joke is in flat, mundane light.

Technical_Cues.Camera: Medium close-up on the main virtuous figure, capturing the emotion of anger being actively controlled.
Technical_Cues.Resolution: 8K, photorealistic, with strong focus on facial expressions conveying complex emotions.
Technical_Cues.Lighting: Rembrandt-style lighting (chiaroscuro) to create a powerful, dramatic mood.
Technical_Cues.Art_Genre: Moralistic historical drama, with a focus on psychological depth.

Cultural_Anchors: The virtue of restraint in anger
